description: From Middle English yerd, yard, »ùerd, »ùeard, from Old English ƒ°eard (‚Äúyard, garden, fence, enclosure‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *gard, from Proto-Germanic *gardaz (‚Äúenclosure, yard‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *g ∞√≥rd ∞os, from Proto-Indo-European *g ∞erd ∞- (‚Äúto enclose‚Äù).

See also Dutch gaard, obsolete German Gart, Swedish, Danish and Norwegian Bokm√•l g√•rd, Norwegian Nynorsk gard, Lithuanian gardas (‚Äúpen, enclosure‚Äù), Russian –≥–æÃÅ—Ä–æ–¥ (g√≥rod, ‚Äútown‚Äù), Serbo-Croatian and Slovene grad ("town"), Albanian gardh (‚Äúfence‚Äù), Romanian gard, Avestan ê¨îê¨Üê¨≠ê¨Üê¨õê¨µê¨Ä‚Äé (g…ôr…ôdha, ‚Äúdev's cave‚Äù), Sanskrit ‡§ó‡•É‡§π (g·πõha)), Medieval Latin gardinus, jardinus. Doublet of garden.

entries.meaning: A small, usually uncultivated area adjoining or (now especially) within the precincts of a house or other building.
(US, Canada, Australia) The property surrounding one's house, typically dominated by one's lawn.
An enclosed area designated for a specific purpose, e.g. on farms, railways etc.
A place where moose or deer herd together in winter for pasture, protection, etc.

verbs.description: yard (third-person singular simple present yards, present participle yarding, simple past and past participle yarded)

description: From Middle English »ùerde, yerd, »ùerd, from Old English ƒ°ierd (‚Äúbranch; rod, staff; measuring stick; yardland‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *ga Äd, from Proto-Germanic *gazdaz. Cognate with Dutch gard (‚Äútwig‚Äù), German Gerte and probably related to Latin hasta (‚Äúspear‚Äù).

entries.meaning: A unit of length equal to 3 feet in the US customary and British imperial systems of measurement, equal to precisely 0.9144¬†m since 1959 (US) or 1963 (UK).
Units of similar composition or length in other systems.

(nautical) A long tapered timber hung on a mast to which is bent a sail, and may be further qualified as a square, lateen, or lug yard. The first is hung at right angles to the mast, the latter two hang obliquely.

examples: [T]he testicles are quite exposed, but they wrap a piece of cloth or leafe round the yard which they tye up to the belly to a cord or bandage which they wear round the waist just under the short ribbs and over the belly and so tight that it was a wonder to us how they could endure it.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The yardland, an obsolete English unit of land roughly understood as 30 acres.
examples: You must note, that two Fardells of Land make a Nooke of Land, and two Nookes make halfe a Yard of Land.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The rod, a surveying unit of (once) 15 or (now) 16+1‚ÅÑ2 feet.
(obsolete) The rood, area bound by a square rod, 1‚ÅÑ4 acre.

verbs.description: yard (third-person singular simple present yards, present participle yarding, simple past and past participle yarded)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, humorous) To move a yard at a time, as opposed to inching along.
(finance) 109, A short scale billion; a long scale thousand millions or milliard.
examples: I need to hedge a yard of yen.
